citation.abstract: Due to increased numbers of young cancer patients and improved survival, the impact of anti-cancer treatments on fertility has become a major health concern. Despite mounting research on ovarian toxicity, there is paucity of data regarding reliable biomarkers of testicular toxicity. Our aim was to evaluate AMH as a marker for chemotherapy-induced testicular toxicity. Serum AMH and a panel of gonadal hormones were measured in male cancer patients at baseline and post-chemotherapy. In the preclinical setting, mice were injected with diverse chemotherapies and were sacrificed 1 week or 1/3/6 months later. We evaluated spermatogenesis by AMH, as well as qualitative and quantitative sperm parameters. Nineteen patients were enrolled, median age was 38y (21-44y). Serum AMH was correlated with increased FSH and testosterone and decreased inhibin-B in gonadotoxic protocols (cisplatin or busulfan), and remained unchanged in non-gonadotoxic protocols (capecitabine). AMH Expression had the same pattern in mice serum and testes; it was negatively correlated with testicular/epididymal weight and sperm motility. The increase in testicular AMH expression was also correlated with elevated apoptosis (TUNEL) and reduced proliferation (Ki67, PCNA; All seminiferous tubules cells were analyzed). Severely damaged mice testes demonstrated a marked co-staining of AMH and GATA-4, a Sertoli-cell marker; staining that resembled the pattern of Sertoli-cell only condition. Our study indicates that the pattern of serum AMH expression, in combination with other hormones, can delineate testicular damage, as determined in both experimental settings. Future large-scale clinical studies are warranted to further define the role of AMH as a biomarker for testicular-toxicity.
citation.title: Anti-Müllerian hormone is a marker for chemotherapy-induced testicular toxicity.
